Comment: This is disingenuous. The issue with secret databases is that people may be on them without their knowledge, and it could be wrong. The UK has had similar issues with the a similar system and it’s the same issues wherever they’re used.  You have younger people being added to them without their knowledge, based on who knows what, and they have no idea they were even profiled or why. Some people may be added to it maliciously, or genuinely by mistake. Maybe they have family or some connection to someone affiliated, maybe they don’t even necessarily know themselves, or maybe they’re connected through some other casual connection. So sometimes it’s like a database of presumed guilt by association.  If social mobility exists then this acts like a straight jacket.  So if that happens, how would they even know? And the answer is they usually don’t even know, but they’ll be scrutinised and policed as if it’s true.  For example, you’re added to the database either my mistake, mistaken identity, misinterpreted signs, or even maliciously by someone that knows someone that has a grudge. So you have a dispute with someone that is connected to law enforcement, they look into the persons background and then add them to the gang database as a method of harassment, essentially, because they will start to notice they are being scrutinised and people are now looking for reasons to justify arresting them. So their life will suddenly become slightly more filled with friction.  Police also leak information, and so the fact that they’re marked won’t be known to them, but it will be to other people, so you may even have other random people/informants then start stalking and surveilling them, under the genuine belief they’re going to find something, and are expecting to collect payments for information. Some vigilantes may then even feel empowered to take extreme steps to find information about them and maybe start trying to bait them into strange situations, they may start to influence people around them and ask questions that lead others to assume something bad is going on.  Because this information leaks, rival gangs may then also get this information so it can then create a genuinely dangerous situation as they may then genuinely believe this person is a fair target and a rival, when there aren’t.  They then do “normal” things like buy certain DIY tools, chemicals, knives etc. The police or informants then start requesting more data about them, surveilling them as from their perspective of “dangerous criminal gang member acquiring weapons and preparing violent assault” etc. Maybe they have a domestic dispute or an argument, this is then escalates m into “dangerous criminal thug danger to life” etc.  If they have money or expensive items, it may by assumed to be the proceeds of crime and interpreted as further evidence of “criminality”, and so again you might then have informants and others trying to “prove” this and take a cut.  So if it turns out that this labelling was wrong, then all this additional policing and scrutiny was unjustified, the person was subjected to surveillance and monitoring and legal harassment that would usually be considered an abuse of a persons rights.  In some cases they’re essentially slandered covertly because if this information leaks and there are informants leaking information that turns out to be false or misleading, then this may affect that persons life. Some background checks and investigations may flag this, and so they may miss opportunities because of it.  So it can be abused in lots of ways that further entrenches social divides because if you’re subjected to this then you’re going to be resentful and distrusting. They may then start to become evasive. This may affect their mental health etc.

Comment: Statistics, no matter what the source, state specific things. They point to nothing.  People use statistics to try to validate their theories or opinions, when in reality, they are just a snapshot of a certain set of facts. There could be a lot of other factors that should be considered before any conclusions are made.  A statistic could be stating that 50% of US citizens are murderers.  It would also happen to be true. A fact.   What isn't stated in this imaginary scenario is that there only happened to be two people in the study, both convicts, and one was, in fact, a murderer.  If you went to a different prison and pulled two inmates, both US citizens, one a murderer and one not, you could formulate a trend. Every time you line up two inmates, one is a murderer. Now you have aligned statistics, multiple studies, even different persons tabulating, and you still get the same statistic- 50% are murderers.  Without the missing context, even with true statistics in that circumstance, the conclusion someone might be led to make would be absolutely faulty.  True statistics can easily be used to tell a lie.  That is embarrassingly common in this arena.
